title: I think IronStylus just inadvertently found a flaw in reddit style posts
body:
[Nearly 2500 comments as of now](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/skin-champion-concepts/oFAWgxY0-community-tell-me-your-skin-ideas?sort_type=best), but nothing more recent than the day it was posted on are in the top of the best view selection.  I've got no problems with the ideas that peculated to the top.  I'm happy for those people.

However 2500 comments is a lot to go through.  I'm not going to lie, that's too much for me to look through and fairly judge.  The fact that some ideas can get visible is a benefit to the system.  However, it also shows an issue that if you don't post something that is popular early in a threads life your chances of getting noticed are a bit low.  

Poor baconavia is just going to be forgotten in the mix.  This isn't because baconavia is a bad idea (I picked a red suggestion on purpose), but it's because baconavia wasn't posted quickly enough.  Had that idea been posted on day two, it probably would have gotten fewer upvotes...  You know, if a red didn't post it.

Has there been any discussion about how to alleviate this issue?  I know there are a tons of great ideas I missed because I don't have time to look through them all.  You are pretty much stuck with best and recent right now.

Edit: there is also no easy way to search within a thread.  I saw two requests for sepiroth Yasuo within a few posts of each other.

replies.body:
Honestly, it's easier for me to digest because people involved in the thread have already helped sort content for me. That's the biggest benefit to the system. Yes, some content won't make it to the top, that's part of the whole voting system. It's ok that some ideas or suggestions don't get up there. There's only so much that can be processed and seen. Realistically not *everything * is going to get up there. I view the cost of a few comments slipping through the cracks as a decent exchange for all the quality stuff that's risen to the top. Believe me, even just the top 10% of that thread is enough to keep me or anyone else busy for a while.

Also, chronological view helps a lot. I toggle back and forth quite a bit. 

Additionally, that thread had a bit of help from Moobeat and Reddit redirecting traffic to it. I'd say that it's not the best example of a case study that exposes a glaring flaw in the system. I was asking for a waterfall of suggestions. That's what I got. In a more discussion based thread, it wouldn't get nearly that amount of unidirectional input.

> Honestly, it's easier for me to digest because people involved in the thread have already helped sort content for me. That's the biggest benefit to the system. Yes, some content won't make it to the top, that's part of the whole voting system. It's ok that some ideas or suggestions don't get up there. There's only so much that can be processed and seen. Realistically not *everything * is going to get up there. I view the cost of a few comments slipping through the cracks as a decent exchange for all the quality stuff that's risen to the top. Believe me, even just the top 10% of that thread is enough to keep me or anyone else busy for a while.

This makes me a little nervous, great parrot overlord.  This implies that in the grand scheme of things, the most popular ideas are the ones that get the most attention, rather than the "best" ones.  I know you personally rarely do this, but.....  Well, I'm sure you can understand my apprehension at hearing this.

:x
Can you define what the difference between "popular" and "best" are?

"Popular" is: Darius is overpowered for bronze and silver players, he needs to be nerfed!
"Best" is: Across all levels of play and including competitive, Darius is severely underpicked and outclassed.

The "popular" post is going to be upvoted by bronze and silver players, a majority of league's population.
The "best" post is going to be upvoted by people with  a brain.

This is a very simple example, I could be a real doucher and use Lee Sin as an example because you know, that is a real example of popular over best.

And despite either format we're still going to read it and take the actions we feel are appropriate in those cases according to external input and internal decision making. 

The real solution is to just put your opinion up and disregard whether your comment is popular or not. Whether your opinion ends up in "best" or "popular", it doesn't really matter, it's still something that will be a good point that we'll take into consideration either way. No one on the dev side is saying "ONLY THOSE THINGS DEEMED POPULAR SHALL PASS!". I think the fear over this sort of thing is blown a bit out of proportion.

Alright so in response to that I will just use that example I said I wouldn't.  Lee Sin.  
Woulda been nerfed if not for popular opinion, despite the Dev's knowing it needed to happen.  

More on topic, I think people are scared that if GD ever ends up dead and everyone is moved over to this format, the sheer number of threads/posts will be too much for Riot to sort through for good ideas.  As a traditional style forum poster and visitor of imageboards over leddit, I prefer the old way.  This format does have its advantages, I agree.  But those advantages are more visible right now with the amount of traffic this version of the forum gets.  If all of GD ever came here, I guarantee you guys wouldn't be able to keep up.  Not saying you guys are gonna give the axe to GD, not putting words in your mouth, just telling you they aren't being blown out of proportion.

I'll submit that despite it reaching 97 upvotes or whatnot, Corporate Vayne is most likely not going to happen. Something that despite that thread showing community support for, to me doesn't seem in line with what we'd do for a Vayne skin. Cute idea but I don't see it happening.

I won't assume to know what the CB team is planning for GD, but I don't think it's going to be nuked from orbit. Currently I will tell you with confidence that GD is difficult to parse. Right now there's no real advantage someone has posting on GD versus over here. Things are equally hard to sort through there due to all the noise. Also, in terms of my areas of interest, I've seen more positive and productive discussions pop up here as of late. 

Fears might be real, it doesn't mean that they're necessarily valid however. I'll say it again.. if someone wants a direct line to me or my team, the best way they can achieve that is through the new boards. That's not me being prickly, it's me saying that the new boards work WAY better for me to glean the feedback I'm looking to deliver to my team. That's just the reality of the situation.

How much of that is due to the small number of posters as compared to GD? Right now, of course it's easier to parse these boards, there are less people posting here and most strict moderation as to what topics go where, so you can easily go in the 'Skin & Champion Concepts' boards and ask for ideas there.

GD, meanwhile, is a smorgasboard of whatever people feel like posting. Occasional mods pop in to delete bad threads or move unrelated threads but GD has been entrenched as 'that place where you post if you want Riot to respond' because Rioters only respond there or the bug forums. If the boards beta becomes 'that place where you post if you want Riot to respond' you're getting a bunch of 'CHAMP OP PLZ NERF' and 'EAST COAST SERVERS WHERE' here. And it's easy to say 'oh, the community will downvote those' but in GD they tend to get lots of upvotes. 

I can understand wanting a new forum, after the terrible mismanagement and culture that's developed the old one. I'm just not a big fan of the reddit style. That's great for news posts, absolute shit for actual discussions.

I have no idea. I don't have the data. But if that skins thread is at all an indication as to how popular feedback can shoot to the top, I'll take it. 

In terms of spam threads making it to the top, that'll be the community's responsibility to manage to a certain degree. Also, if it's just spam that has no value, no dev will bother posting in there.

I'll just have to take your word for it that people are actually reading the later comments to a thread. Not that that's anything new, I guess.

I get that you want community moderation, but who do you think it is that's making those threads?  The snide comments about East Coast Servers tend to always get upvoted, the 'champ OP nerf plz' threads get upvoted if they're about whatever champ GD has decided is OP this week, etc. No, it might not attract dev attention, but it might overpower the rest of that subforum if 'hot' or 'best' is selected.

Well, I read the stuff. I have 2000+ replies to that skins thread in my inbox and anything I deem appropriate is currently going into a very long spreadsheet. So I guess feel free to have doubts, you're welcome to them, but I'm doing my best to do my due diligence. 

Yeah, that stuff might get upvoted, but again, if collectively you want discussion to be meaningful, you'll do your part to upvote or downvote. I'm sure if something gets out of hand moderation on this side of things will happen.

> Well, I read the stuff. I have 2000+ replies to that skins thread in my inbox and anything I deem appropriate is currently going into a very long spreadsheet. So I guess feel free to have doubts, you're welcome to them, but I'm doing my best to do my due diligence. 

I guess now would be a good time to thank you for going through them. I've always enjoyed that you were one Rioter I can count on to talk about things. Shame you're not in lore.
> Yeah, that stuff might get upvoted, but again, if collectively you want discussion to be meaningful, you'll do your part to upvote or downvote. I'm sure if something gets out of hand moderation on this side of things will happen.

I want discussion to be meaningful. I can't speak for anyone else, and given the examples I can see on GD, I'm not very hopeful.

> Well, I read the stuff. I have 2000+ replies to that skins thread in my inbox and anything I deem appropriate is currently going into a very long spreadsheet. So I guess feel free to have doubts, you're welcome to them, but I'm doing my best to do my due diligence. 

I can believe you when you say that, but I'd really appreciate it if you'd say that sort of thing earlier.  It feels like you're taking on a condescending tone, which would be really unfair. We have very little information (often none) about the way you're taking in our posts. I didn't know about your spreadsheet until just now, and I doubt I'm alone in that.

Wouldn't it simply be best to look at the "problem" from a solution perspective?

Posts after the thread reaches, say, 100 posts are highly unlikely to be read, and thus garner minimal upvotes, and thus stagnate or take forever to percolate upwards.

I'm sure that you guys can analyze the data to view the percentage of thread readers that upvote a post, sorted by its distance from the top of the page.
Then its just a matter of providing upvotes increased power on new posts, based on their distance from the top of the thread.

So if the average post in a "hot" thread, with 50 posts above it (including nested) gets 2 upvotes/hour, while the top 5 posts accrue 10-30/hour, then the system could simply apply that to a new thread as such:
If a new post is made 90 minutes after the thread become front-page material, and is deemed to gain upvotes at about 10% the speed of top posts, then if it receives 10% as many upvotes during the first 30 minutes of its life, than the board can elevate it to within the top 10 posts.

Once this "potential" post has been elevated, the system merely needs to compare the votes it gets to the votes the other top posts are receiving, and move it up/down based on that.
Once moved, an arbitrary number of upvotes is the threshold (lets say 50).  After any top post receives 50 upvotes, the "potential" post is checked for its votes, and moved to a proper position in the thread based on that comparison, with its upvotes artificially adjusted to make it have the right number for its new position.
No further attention needs to be paid to that post, since it has the proper votes for its position, and will receive the attention it has earned.

That's implying that the only thing people use forums for is to communicate their opinions to the devs. Lots of people use these forums to talk with their fellow League players and catch up with the trends. Those are the people I'm worried about when I'm talking about how no one sees the later posts of a thread because no one's upvoting them.

Also, pardon me for being a skeptic, but I severely doubt that a Rioter can read every post of a 2500 post thread full of actual discussion and possible hard maths. I guess it might be easy for a 'give us ideas for skins' thread like the one you posted, but if that was a balance discussion or something along those lines, I'd feel really discouraged that Statikk/Morello/Ghostcrawler/Xypherous/whoever won't see my post because it's behind a bunch of thick posts.

No, that's the specific case of 1) dev asking for feedback and 2) players providing feedback.

Obviously the boards have several different uses and aren't going to be relegated to be a one-way street to dev-land. 

Be as skeptical as you like. I encourage you to be. Be critical and offer solutions to the team developing these boards. And do it now while there's less of a population, as you've stated, you'll be a larger voice in a smaller group of people. Better chances of being heard.

In terms of design discussions, I have yet to be involved in them. The type of engagement I have is based on more of casting a wide net in looking for player consensus to manifest. But at least in terms of having discussions about art and a few other things, I haven't yet had any significant issues carrying on productive back-and-forth now that discussion and chronological views are an option.

> No, that's the specific case of 1) dev asking for feedback and 2) players providing feedback.
> 
> Obviously the boards have several different uses and aren't going to be relegated to be a one-way street to dev-land. 

I can understand how from a dev's perspective, you enjoy being able to look at a thread and be able to, at a glance, figure out what opinions are popular amongst the playerbase. I understand that you apparently go through the less popular opinions as well. But amongst other players, I severely doubt that many will put in the effort. The League forums are already an echo chamber, full of people agreeing with people who have had the same opinion since the thread started, and this would merely make it worse.
> Be as skeptical as you like. I encourage you to be. Be critical and offer solutions to the team developing these boards. And do it now while there's less of a population, as you've stated, you'll be a larger voice in a smaller group of people. Better chances of being heard.

Unfortunately, my suggestion of 'burn it down, start over' was not received very well amongst the dev team.

> I severely doubt that a Rioter can read every post of a 2500 post thread full of actual discussion and possible hard maths

Yes, this is something I feel is an issue.  Even if I have the time to go through that much writing, I might not feel like it as an average joe.

"Popular" is objective. If a lot of people know about and claim to enjoy/appreciate a thing, that's just statistical fact. "A lot" might be up for debate, but once it has a definition "popular" is just not an actually arguable thing.

"Best" is subjective. Even if every aspect of it could be defined, the fulfillment of that definition won't be *strictly* true outside of individual perception.

That's a lot of granular semantics. Yes, popular opinions are going to rise to the top. But no one is just going to look at the top most upvoted comment and say "WELP. GUESS WE'LL JUST DO THAT". On the contrary, we might see a popular opinion rocket to the top that despite being popular, is something that internally we have to act in the opposite direction. 

I hear the concerns, but I just don't yet see a reason to be scared. I still read the entire thread :P

No, people in the thread haven't helped you sort the content.  It just LOOKS like they did.  This has been one of the complaints about the Reddit style board from the beginning.  The "rich get richer" problem.  If a thread only has a few replies, sure, better posts make it to the top.  The problem is, a week later, when the thread has a hundred or a thousand replies, those same posts are still at the top.  Not because they are necessarily better, but because they were the best of the first 20 or so posts.  NOBODY is reading the entire thread.  Do you understand that?  NOBODY.  The early upvoted posts keep getting more upvotes, making them seem ludicrously popular, when the truth is they get upvotes simply because they are already in a position where everyone reads them.

YOU may use chronological view, but I will bet my life's savings that the majority of people upvoting the top posts are not switching to chronological view to see if a better idea was presented since they last looked at the thread.  Out of the later posts, chronological view may allow you to see, say, a skin idea YOU like and it'll get put in the works... but you won't get any idea of what the community wants.   There could be literally HUNDREDS of skins in that thread that would get even more upvotes than the top ideas already in the thread... but the Reddit style forums won't let that happen.  Almost ALL discussion will center around the top few ideas from early on, and since those ideas are very popular, almost all the discussion will be positive.  Hence the term "Reddit circle jerk."

So.. a thread of hundreds of skin ideas, in a view that moves popular content to be more easily visible to the devs is less valuable than a thread of hundreds of individual posts saying completely different things, with the only way to look at popularity is by scrolling through page-by-page looking for the little green numbers?

Speaking from the dev side of things, I'm going to get a lot more information, actionable information, from a non-linear thread in the specific case of the skins thread.

I didn't say less valuable, and to imply that is to put words in my mouth.  I said, as I did months ago, that the "rich get richer" problem absolutely must be addressed in order for these forums (still refusing to call them by the dumb new name) to have value.  I don't think GD or the old way of doing the forums worked well.  I also don't think this works better unless you address the problems inherent in the system.  (Of course, at the same time, you could have just addressed the problem inherent in the old system and accomplished the same thing.  Riot's nerdgasm over Reddit is still something that eludes my understanding.)

My point is you AREN'T actually getting a lot more actionable information from the "top posts" feature.  The top posts in that thread have remained the same ALMOST THE ENTIRE EXISTENCE OF THE THREAD.  You've had to dig far deeper, and switch to chronological view, in order to increase the information you get.  The advantage of the chronological ordering of GD is that the most recent posts do get lots of attention.  Plenty of people would read the first page of a thread, skip ahead to the last couple of pages and read those to catch up on the discussion, and go from there.

Let's compare the two.  Here, most posters are upvoting and commenting on the top posts... and you've been watching them do that for the entire life of the thread.  Every day, you check the thread and get to see, not what new skin is rising in popularity... but how many more people joined the circle jerk of whatever the top posts already are.  In chronological view (with that as the only option) you see a lot more discussion on the final pages about more recent skin ideas.  Yes, in both, some get lost in the cracks.  I'd argue fewer get lost in the cracks with the chronological view than with this boondoggle.

Solutions?  That is tough.  I've thought about it a lot and come up with very little.  A significant daily decay in the upvotes of a post could help... or a system where the average upvotes per hour are calculated, allowing new posts that are getting a lot of attention to rise the top where more people will see it.  As those posts get older, and if you don't allow multiple upvotes from the same person, the upvotes per hour will drop and another post will rise.

The solution is to do the manual labor of going through the thread. That's about it. 

Also, I'm stating the straight up fact, from the dev side, that I can glean a lot more information, or, and this is key, **all the information I can reasonably handle**, from the top chunk of the thread. 

On GD it's a lot more tedious to check every single post which on face value has about as equal amount of visual and informational weight upon first read. Have you honestly gone through 50 pages of individual posts? It's impossible to handle. getting say.. 40% of popular content suggestion.. is far better than me throwing up my hands because I'm exhausted from examining the thread post-by-post. 

Even linear threads have diminishing returns. The longer it goes on, the less anyone is going to be motivated to post or read. At least here on these boards, that burst of enthusiasm is easily gleaned and able to be cultivated. And If time allows, I can sort through the thread with different tools. 

The system is never going to be perfect, but getting the top 40% of information, and that's generalizing to an extreme, is really valuable, and is about as much as someone like me can reasonably handle incorporating into action.

You keep saying that "I'm not getting the most valuable information", but I actually am, for my goals. I don't exactly know how to argue the reality that I experience from this side of things. I guess we have to agree to disagree.

I think you sort of miss the point made in this thread.

Though it appears to sort out valuable information on the boards due to popularity, it mostly comes down to First come, first served. It´s just the exact same as it would be in GD if you would just read the first 40%of the pages, nothing is added to it.

I think noone here really expects you to read through 2000+posts, that would be rather ridiculous - but the fact remains that the "reddit-system" is far from being a good solution to make Posts visible that have high value. Quite the opposite, it really hurts Threads that are posted at a time when Forum-activity is low/or that get randomly downvoted asap and posts that are done after the first wave of popular-posts is already established.

So I think it comes down to this Format being a big imposter, while GD does kinda offer the same, but in a more honest fashion currently. There really still is a lot to do to make the new board a better experience.

I'll still stand by the notion that the format is viewed as an anathema because of an inherent revulsion certain members have as a pre-existing bias. They bring their concerns about reddit here and fear the same results they see as negatives in the discussion based format. I can understand it, but I've seen far more benefit than detriment. You want your voice heard? Continue to speak! It's really that simple. The same concerns I've heard about the discussion format are the same problems I've experienced on GD. "Circlejerks", upvoted/bumped spam, voices not being heard, etc. Those problems exist and worse on GD in my opinion as things currently stand. 

I don't think there's any evidence, at least that would convince me, that this format hurts discussion. My experience has been different. Also, considering I've experienced **none** of the toxicity I've run into on GD over in this neck of the woods, I'd say the experience has been pretty good.  Things stay on track, interactions have been polite and spirited and discussions have been easily tracked.

First off, not an anti-Reddit partisan. I've never used Reddit, and have only the foggiest idea why some people have such antipathy towards it. Boards is definitely a step up overall, though it will be interesting to see how it scales up as more people migrate over.

I do have one challenge in carrying on a conversation on the boards. If I'm talking to someone, and it's not in a popular thread of the discussion, I'll often struggle to post in it again. Clicking on their post from my updates doesn't always take me there, and it then takes a large number of somewhat blind expands and searches to find their response to me.

Certainly, this is no worse than in the classical threaded structure, where I'd have to search a potentially large number of pages, and wouldn't have the updates to help out. Still, it's an element of the system that could use improvement.

Also, this structure makes it harder for discussions to evolve. I've seen some good threads that start out on one topic, and end up about something entirely different. That's harder here.

> I'll still stand by the notion that the format is viewed as an anathema because of an inherent revulsion certain members have as a pre-existing bias. They bring their concerns about reddit here and fear the same results they see as negatives in the discussion based format. I can understand it, but I've seen far more benefit than detriment. You want your voice heard? Continue to speak! It's really that simple. The same concerns I've heard about the discussion format are the same problems I've experienced on GD. "Circlejerks", upvoted/bumped spam, voices not being heard, etc. Those problems exist and worse on GD in my opinion as things currently stand. 

At first this sounds like reasonable advice.  The problem is that if you want to talk about something that most people will just upvote and move on, you'll be making the same thread multiple times a day and then the mods will come after you for spamming.  For example, if I made a thread right now discussing the absolutely abominable particle/hitbox mismatches present on a number of abilities, I'd initially get a bunch of upvotes, an bunch of posts saying "yeah I agree X happened to me!", and that's it.  Nobody would actually have anything else to say on the matter, and the discussion would quickly fall off the front page.  Let's be honest here, the only reason this thread is still alive is because you personally are still here discussing it.  If you stopped replying, this thread would die almost immediately, and would quickly drop off the page as more champion suggestions (that I'm pretty sure Riot doesn't even look at on principle?) come and go, washing this thread away with them.
 
> I don't think there's any evidence, at least that would convince me, that this format hurts discussion. My experience has been different. Also, considering I've experienced **none** of the toxicity I've run into on GD over in this neck of the woods, I'd say the experience has been pretty good.  Things stay on track, interactions have been polite and spirited and discussions have been easily tracked.

And in my experience, I've watched utter nonsense threads stick on the front page for days while legitimate discussion gets upvotes but not comments and slides away into obscurity.

> Also, considering I've experienced **none** of the toxicity I've run into in GD over in this neck of the woods,

We've had this conversation before.  Over the past 5 years, Riot staff have (unintentionally) conditioned the forumgoing playerbase that if you want Riot to read what you type out, you have to post it in GD.  This leads to anyone wanting anyone to read anything needing to post it in GD.  Because the overwhelming majority of people are in GD, the trolls will be in GD.  Combine that with the...  lackluster moderation over the years and you get today's GD.  I'm really tired of hearing this implication from Tamat that GD is the spawn of all evil because it's GD.  It got this way because of how Rioters interacted with it.  It didn't just magically occur on it's own.

I think your POV is a little slanted here. As the OP you are getting a msg of every post that is throwing an idea at you. You get to see a new reply directly to your post. 

But for the people that are coming in it will not be doing that. They are going to see the Top 50 so posts and then leave it at that. The top post are usually posts that come for day 1. This is cause those early posts are going to get more visible traffic. If someone has a great idea day 3 or POV on a topic responding directly to the original post is not going to get seen by many people. Their are people that have been reading and up-voting specific posts and they are at 10+.

This board rewards people who were first. Sure people have to vote but i have seen people up vote some really bad ideas before. You said again in this thread that the community will filter. This has never worked before and will not work with Riot. 

According to some poll data most of the forum goers are 15-18. So you are asking people that as a culture that we say are not legally capable for their decisions, to filter things for on the forums. You got to joking.

>You want your voice heard? Continue to speak! It's really that simple.

I´m pretty sure everyone wants their voice heard, though this sort of is a problem here - as the first voices will become the loudest voices very quickly + there´s no option to bump a thread if you posted it on a bad time to be heard (low activity)...so the only option is reposting the same thing over and over. Not sure if that´s a great solution.

>The same concerns I've heard about the discussion format are the same problems I've experienced on GD. "Circlejerks", upvoted/bumped spam, voices not being heard, etc. Those problems exist and worse on GD in my opinion as things currently stand. 

Not disagreeing here entirely, but that´s just the problem I have with the Boards currently. Instead of trying to fix some issues that are present it seems like all you want to achieve is recoulouring the same old thing. So the Problems remain on the new Boards aswell

>I don't think there's any evidence, at least that would convince me, that this format hurts discussion. My experience has been different.

This is another part where I think the Boards are pretty imissleading:
Yes, it´s very conveniant to have a 1 on 1 Discussion, as the personal inbox makes it very easy to follow responses and respond to them. Really a great improvement right there...the problem however is, the discussion shifts into privacy if it goes on over some back and forth, no matter how good it is. In the GD-format the discussions where a lot more public and visible...here they tend to disappear behind a big wall of "show more"-buttons, no matter how good they turn out to be (long back and forths tend to be the most productive sort of discussions, at least if both sides are open-minded)

>Also, considering I've experienced none of the toxicity I've run into on GD over in this neck of the woods, I'd say the experience has been pretty good. Things stay on track, interactions have been polite and spirited and discussions have been easily tracked.

I think this really comes down to the people attending the Boards, not to the mechanisms of the Boards itself. As a F.E.K. user i only have a small amount of People in the GD Blacklisted and it is quite a peacefull place for me most of the times with some rather good discussions (and some nonsense here and there, but well...it´s GD after all). I too enjoy the atmosphere on these Boards currently, no doubt about that - but it is really unrelated to the deeper problems that run with the visability-mechanisms.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

I´m really not opposing these Boards...I like the coulours, I really like the inbox (though for me personally the my-updates page seems to be down today for some reason) - I think it has great potential. But I also think it needs more confidence to aspire sth more than being a sort of reddit 2.0. THe current Format doesn´t solve any issues the old GD had, it only recolours them.

Oh, okay... so there isn't actually any interest on the dev side for improving the boards during beta.  The beta is really just about changing the color scheme until it's snazzy, and the feedback section is just a reacharound to make the players feel better.

Yes, we can agree to disagree.  You and the other devs can keep living with the delusion that Reddit style is amazing and not try to fix any of the problems that have been pointed out with it.  If there is no interest in actually improving the boards, then there is no reason for any of us to bother interacting with you here.  You might as well just delete the "Boards Feedback" section.

Of course there's interest in that. I'm not on that team, but they're certainly committed to improvements. I don't know whet to tell you honestly. But calling us delusional and firing accusations of feedback processes being a "reacharound" isn't helping me sympathize with your position.

Oh, when I offered a detailed analysis of the problem with a potential solution, and you just brushed it off... I might have made the assumption you weren't interested in sympathizing with our position.  (Not my position.  You can look throughout the entire thread and find a ton of people who agree.)

And a feedback process that does not produce changes that the community desires is most accurately described as a reacharound.  It is indicative of an act meant to distract from the fact that you are getting bent over.  I'm sorry if that is too vulgar for your sensitive tastes, but I strive for effective imagery.

You could at least notice that IronStylus is actually talking to you.  Or perhaps you haven't noticed that Riot has more or less clammed up.  Raging at him is not going to make our collective point any stronger.  It will undermine it, in fact.

A responsive member of the dev team isn't all that useful if that responsiveness does not translate to action of any kind.  You speak as if there is anything to undermine.  It was already made clear, they don't care about how strong an argument we make on the matter.  All I'm doing is stating the facts as I see them. In the latter case the little green numbers actually tell you a fairly comparable number, as all the posts beyond the first 2-3 pages get about the same amount of visibility as they are in the last page for roughly the same amount of time. 

Over here you can easily tell which idea is popular, but the extent of the popularity is not measurable because of the of the circlejerk. There is no way to know how many upvotes an idea, that now has 30 and was submitted one day after the thread was made, would have had if it had been one of the very first posts. It could be anything from a hundred to thousands. Because of this you can't really get a true estimate of how many people really perceive the idea as good compared to others.

I do understand that you can never just compare ideas based on the amount of upvotes only, and I understand that you may only be watching for ideas that have achieved at least some popularity without really caring if it has 20 or 20 000 upvotes. How are we supposed to know if you actually have time to go though our feedback before starting your iterations? Most people can't honestly say that they would read too many of the "buried" comments, which normally means that neither would you.
